page.title: 15LOCAL HISTORY.
page.content: { OWSTON'S MEDIAEVAL MONASTERY { }Owston was once a centre of ancient routes and its church is the surviving relic of an Augustinian abbey founded in 1161. There is Norman stonework on the south side, the north aisle and arches are thirteenth century, the tower fourteenth century, and the parapet and spire early sixteenth century. Earthworks are evident in neighbouring fields to west and south, and some of these, together with a small lake, are the remains of mediaeval fish ponds. The abbey would have farmed all the surrounding countryside and a moated site half_way to Knossington was a fortified granary.Hedges surrounding the village are about{400}years old, possibly established after the Dissolution. A pump commemorates the Palmers of Withcote who once owned the village.
